<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 390, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 195, 907, 210]]<|/det|>
9709/72  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 217, 907, 232]]<|/det|>
May/June 2011  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 239, 907, 254]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 606, 525]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 571]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The weights of bags of fuel have mean \(3.2 \mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(0.04 \mathrm{kg}\). The total weight of a random sample of three bags is denoted by \(T \mathrm{kg}\). Find the mean and standard deviation of \(T\). [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 136, 97, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
\(X\) is a random variable having the distribution \(\mathsf{B}\big(12, \frac{1}{4}\big)\). A random sample of 60 values of \(X\) is taken. Find the probability that the sample mean is less than 2.8. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 198, 94, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 920, 232]]<|/det|>
The number of goals scored per match by Everly Rovers is represented by the random variable \(X\) which has mean 1.8.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 246, 151, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 244, 698, 263]]<|/det|>
State two conditions for \(X\) to be modelled by a Poisson distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 245, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 275, 364, 293]]<|/det|>
Assume now that \(X \sim \mathrm{Po}(1.8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 306, 151, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 306, 311, 324]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(2 < X < 6)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 306, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 337, 153, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 337, 920, 371]]<|/det|>
The manager promises the team a bonus if they score at least 1 goal in each of the next 10 matches. Find the probability that they win the bonus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 352, 920, 371]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 400, 94, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
A doctor wishes to investigate the mean fat content in low-fat burgers. He takes a random sample of 15 burgers and sends them to a laboratory where the mass, in grams, of fat in each burger is determined. The results are as follows.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 456, 794, 475]]<|/det|>
9 7 8 9 6 11 7 9 8 9 8 10 7 9 9

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 483, 920, 516]]<|/det|>
Assume that the mass, in grams, of fat in low-fat burgers is normally distributed with mean \(\mu\) and that the population standard deviation is 1.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 530, 146, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 499, 548]]<|/det|>
Calculate a \(99\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 530, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 561, 151, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 561, 915, 579]]<|/det|>
Explain whether it was necessary to use the Central Limit theorem in the calculation in part **(i)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 577, 920, 594]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 606, 151, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 606, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
The manufacturer claims that the mean mass of fat in burgers of this type is \(8 \mathrm{g}\). Use your answer to part **(i)** to comment on this claim.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 622, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 668, 96, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 668, 920, 717]]<|/det|>
The number of adult customers arriving in a shop during a 5-minute period is modelled by a random variable with distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(6)\). The number of child customers arriving in the same shop during a 10-minute period is modelled by an independent random variable with distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(4.5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 731, 153, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 731, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that during a randomly chosen 2-minute period, the total number of adult and child customers who arrive in the shop is less than 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 747, 920, 765]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 778, 153, 795]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 777, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
During a sale, the manager claims that more adult customers are arriving than usual. In a randomly selected 30-minute period during the sale, 49 adult customers arrive. Test the manager's claim at the \(2.5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 809, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Jeevan thinks that a six-sided die is biased in favour of six. In order to test this, Jeevan throws the die 10 times. If the die shows a six on at least 4 throws out of 10, she will conclude that she is correct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 120, 153, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 551, 139]]<|/det|>
State appropriate null and alternative hypotheses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 151, 153, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 495, 170]]<|/det|>
Calculate the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 182, 151, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 182, 616, 201]]<|/det|>
Explain what is meant by a Type II error in this situation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 182, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 214, 151, 232]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 214, 920, 247]]<|/det|>
If the die is actually biased so that the probability of throwing a six is \(\frac{1}{2}\), calculate the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 233, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 276, 94, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 276, 620, 295]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 298, 630, 338]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}k(1 - x) & -1\leqslant x\leqslant 1,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 292, 361]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 374, 153, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 373, 292, 392]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{1}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 374, 920, 392]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 406, 151, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 406, 280, 425]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X > \frac{1}{2})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 406, 920, 425]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 438, 151, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 438, 320, 457]]<|/det|>
Find the mean of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 438, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 470, 148, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 470, 403, 489]]<|/det|>
Find \(a\) such that \(\mathrm{P}(X < a) = \frac{1}{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 470, 920, 489]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
